;当超级英雄电影最好的部分是剧本时，您就知道自己处于其中麻烦。 《漫威》中有足够多的故事情节——足够多具有戏剧性潜力的场景，足够多具有想象力的曲折——可以拍出几部像样的电影。不幸的是，它们被剪断、剪断、卡住、撞击，以一种信息冷漠的方式被扔进电影（又被扫出电影），甚至没有速度的优点。不经意地急于将故事搬上银幕，导致了对描绘故事的强大人才的惊人浪费。

;

;这里有很多未开发的元素，但最基本的元素之一是戏剧道德：悲剧的模式是美德的冲突，但《漫威》中几乎没有任何恶行，每个人或多或少都有自己的理由。这部电影由 Nia DaCosta（与 Megan McDonnell 和 Elissa Karasik 共同撰写剧本）执导，是 2019 年电影《;惊奇队长;。”在那里，获得超能力（以及称号的绰号）的美国空军飞行员卡罗尔·丹弗斯（布丽·拉尔森饰）被卷入两个太空民族克里人和斯库鲁人之间的战争。在接下来的剧情中，丹弗斯被指控无意中熄灭了使克里人和斯库鲁人的星球适宜居住的太阳，他生活在一种充满负罪感、自我强加的太空流放之中。复仇者联盟的经纪人尼克·弗瑞（塞缪尔·杰克逊饰）将她召回，修复所谓的“跳跃点”，一种空间传送门。一位名叫莫妮卡·兰博（泰柔娜·帕里斯饰）的宇航员加入了这次任务，她在上一部电影中还是个孩子。他们的工作让他们通过一种奇怪的星际联系，接触到泽西城的青少年卡玛拉·汗（伊曼·韦拉尼饰），他是惊奇队长漫画书的忠实粉丝，也拥有秘密的超能力，并有一个特殊的发光手套来证明这一点。这副手套是一对中的一个，其中另一个由一位名叫达尔-本（扎威·阿什顿饰）的克里战士拥有。她憎恨惊奇队长摧毁了她的星球，并试图通过抓住卡玛拉的手套来最大限度地发挥自己的力量。与此同时，当莫妮卡和惊奇队长在跳跃点相遇时，他们和卡玛拉都交换了位置，从而使彼此的战斗突然变成了自己的战斗。

;

;结果包括几场对决——一场在汗家的房子里，有几个在外太空，还有一些在宇宙飞船上进行大胆的尝试。还有一些温和的家庭情景喜剧，涉及卡玛拉的父母（泽诺比亚·史洛夫和莫汉·卡普尔饰）和她的哥哥（萨加尔·谢赫饰），令父母沮丧的是，她的哥哥仍未结婚。有一些直率和笨拙的喜剧涉及惊奇队长与王子（朴叙俊饰）的权宜婚姻，在一个居民仅通过歌曲交流的星球上。卡玛拉对惊奇队长的尴尬迷恋中充满了精心设计的甜蜜喜剧。惊奇队长的猫有一个奇特之处，它的嘴里长着几码长的触手，它可以吞下比自己大很多倍的生物，然后将它们完好无损地吐出来。帮助现在成为难民的斯库鲁人找到家园的努力具有政治意义。最重要的是，其中有一些巨大的人造科学的胡言乱语，涉及时空连续体的撕裂，这可能而且也许应该是一部完全独立的电影，并配有与之相匹配的特效。

;
;
;

;这些众多元素中的任何一个，尽管可能显而易见且熟悉，都可以作为流行动作奇幻的框架。事实上，没有一个主角犯了严重的错误，所有人都以不同的方式追求有价值的目标，这也让事情变得复杂。我对这部电影寄予厚望的另一个原因是达科斯塔的上一部电影，“;在 18 世纪 90 年代中期;不可能完成的。 )

;您可以通过“漫威”的严格格式赋予演员强大的方式来看到这一点拉尔森、帕里斯和新人维拉尼（她的第一个电影角色）没什么可做的。他们所要求的表演只是将瞬间的情感象征化，比如人性化的表情符号。拉尔森以一种坚定的严厉态度做到了这一点，这比纯粹的阵营还差一步，我希望她能释放出这种态度。我总能在她的举止中发现某种本质上的尚武精神，回想一下她在 2013 年独立电影《;短期 12;。”我怀疑她认为超级英雄角色比许多她这种水平的演员在艺术上更令人满意，我希望这部电影能给她空间和时间来探索这一点。 （也就是说，让戏剧表演的简单力量出现在像《漫威》这样完美的电影中可能会在它自己的时空连续体上炸出一个洞。）

;

;最近的发展之一漫威系列中受到了达科斯塔、赵婷和佩顿·里德等极具特色的电影制作人的欢迎。这本应保证电影创意的范围不断扩大——并有预算（以及片尾字幕中列出的大量技术人员）作为支持。相反，他们的个人艺术很大程度上被特许经营的生产系统所主导和压倒。尽管为扩大超级英雄电影的创意团队并使之多样化做出了种种努力，但它们的主要创作者却是一群古板而年长的白人。当然，我指的是美国国会，国会在 1976 年和 1998 年两次延长了版权条款，以便根据所谓的米老鼠保护法，1978 年之前出版的作品可以保留在公司之下。控制了九十五年。因此，即使是现在，许多经典的漫画超级英雄仍然距离公共领域数十年，距离从企业权利持有者手中解放出来还有数十年的时间。漫画故事的影响力和范围——它们所设想的广阔宇宙和它们激发的热情奉献——可以说使它们成为我们当代的古代宗教文本。但是，只要个别工作室保留版权，就好像所有圣经人物和故事的表现都由梵蒂冈控制。其结果是让超级英雄电影和好莱坞的大部分电影都处于一种人为的不成熟状态，这与衰老没有什么区别。电影中的广阔宇宙比生活窄得多。 ♦

;周三下午，法官阿瑟·恩戈隆 (Arthur F. Engoron) 驳回了伊万卡·特朗普 (Ivanka Trump) 的诉讼出庭作证，纽约总检察长办公室搁置了针对;唐纳德·特朗普;的民事欺诈案，他的;两个长子;和特朗普组织。曾担任特朗普集团高管、白宫官员和一家服装企业老板的伊万卡大步走出法庭，不久之后，纽约县以外就传来欢呼声和嘲笑声。法院大楼里聚集了一小群围观者。

;

;2022 年 9 月，州总检察长利蒂西亚·詹姆斯 (Letitia James) ;首先对特朗普家族提出民事指控;，伊万卡是共同被告。然而，今年六月，上诉法院驳回了她的案件，理由是针对她的索赔已受到州诉讼时效限制。 （她于 2017 年离开特朗普集团，与丈夫一起在白宫担任助手;极大地夸大了特朗普的净资产，以帮助该公司从银行和其他金融机构那里获得有利的交易。总检察长办公室的高级律师路易斯·所罗门 (Louis Solomon) 带领伊万卡查阅了与她广泛参与的两处特朗普地产相关的一系列文件和电子邮件：迈阿密的多拉尔高尔夫度假村，特朗普集团购买并重新开发了该地产，以及位于华盛顿特区的政府拥有的旧邮局大楼，特朗普集团租用了该大楼并将其改造成一家豪华酒店。

;

;过去六周以来，该试验的大部分内容包括：同样费力的练习还涉及其他证人，包括伊万卡的父亲和两个兄弟。但是，如果周三诉讼的基本形式很熟悉的话，伊万卡的行为与其家人的行为之间的对比是显而易见的。从始至终，她都彬彬有礼。她笑了。她甚至与喜欢开玩笑的恩戈隆法官交换了一两句轻松的话。总而言之，她上演了一场令人印象深刻的表演，但最终还是建立在严重的选择性失忆症的基础上。

;

;所罗门一次又一次地问伊万卡是否记得某些通讯或认出某些展品。而且，伊万卡一次又一次地说她没有。其中许多通信涉及德意志银行，该银行向特朗普集团提供低成本贷款，为多拉尔的重建和旧邮局大楼的改建提供资金。所罗门制作了一份 2011 年 11 月的文件，其中德意志银行的证券部门（与私人财富部门分开运营）提出向多拉尔提供贷款，利率等于伦敦银行间同业拆借利率（LIBOR） ;）加上百分之八。伊万卡说她不记得曾见过这些条款。随后，所罗门出示了德意志银行私人财富部门高级管理人员罗斯玛丽·弗拉布利奇 (Rosemary Vrablic) 2011 年 12 月发送的一封电子邮件，其中包含为多拉尔项目提供两笔贷款的提议，利率等于伦敦银行同业拆借利率 (LIBOR)。 em>; 加 2% 和 2.5%。不需要金融奇才就能明白，;LIBOR; 加 2% 的利率比 ;LIBOR; 加 8% 的利率要好得多。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;伊万卡说她回忆起自己“获得了很高的评价”来自 Vrablic 的“级别术语”，但她说她不记得这个特定的提议。所罗门随后制作了一封电子邮件，伊万卡在弗拉布利奇向她发送电子邮件后不久发送给了其他特朗普高管，其中她转发了银行家提供的贷款条款。 “没有比这更好的了。让我们尽快讨论，”电子邮件中说道。所罗门读完后问证人：“这是否让你想起这对特朗普集团来说是否是一个好的提议？”伊万卡回答说：“我认为我们最终所做的略有不同。但是，是的，我认为总体来说这笔交易是积极的。”

;
;
;

;德意志银行提供的两笔贷款之间的一个关键区别在于，私人财富部门提供的贷款要求特朗普的个人担保和证券部门的个人担保都没有。所罗门调出了伊万卡从特朗普集团律师贾森·格林布拉特那里收到的一封电子邮件，格林布拉特在邮件中指出，弗拉布利奇的提议要求特朗普亲自为贷款提供担保，并保持至少30亿美元的净资产，这对特朗普来说是一个巨大的挑战。 “在我看来这是一个问题吗？”正如格林布拉特所说。伊万卡回答说：“我们从第一天起就知道了。我们希望获得优惠的利率，而获得我们想要的收益/期限和原则的唯一方法就是保证交易。”所罗门询问证人是否记得写过这封电子邮件。不，她回答道。

;所有这一切的目的是试图证明特朗普至少部分基于他在财务状况声明中声称的净资产而获得了有利的贷款条件。伊万卡表示，她与这些声明的准备无关，对这些声明知之甚少。但所罗门还出示了 2012 年与德意志银行签订的最终贷款协议的副本。其中包括 25 亿美元的最低净资产要求，并指出特朗普已向该银行提供了他的财务报表副本。

;
;
;

;偶尔，伊万卡能够唤起一些更详细的记忆。她记得最初通知她特朗普家族可以购买多拉的信是在她即将生孩子时出现的。她还详细回忆了 2011 年在华盛顿特区与联邦总务管理局举行的一次会议，会上她、她的父亲和特朗普的其他高管提出了重建旧邮局大楼的愿景。但她坚称，她不记得与 GSA 讨论过任何有关特朗普财务报表的事情。“当我问问题时，她不记得了，”沮丧的所罗门对恩戈隆法官说道。 “法官大人，证人确实有记忆！”

;

;就连司法部长似乎也对伊万卡在证人席上的流畅表现印象深刻。詹姆斯在法院外对记者说：“伊万卡·特朗普很热情，她遵守纪律，她很有控制力，而且她非常有礼貌。”然而，总检察长接着说，文件证据清楚地表明，证人“为了特朗普集团、特朗普先生和她的兄弟以及她自己的利益，参与谈判和获得贷款、优惠贷款。” 。 。 。文件不会说谎。数字不会说谎。”

;

;在一个严重依赖文件的案件中，这就是特朗普辩护团队面临的挑战。从周一开始，他们将试图说服法院，文件证据虽然数量庞大，但并不能证明特朗普和特朗普集团存在欺诈意图，也不能证明财务状况声明中包含的虚假估值对公司造成了任何财务损害。接受这些文件的银行和其他金融公司。

;

;在伊万卡离开证人席之前，特朗普辩护团队成员耶稣·苏亚雷斯 (Jesus Suarez) 通过盘问她关于特朗普组织的行为，开始了这一努力。与德意志银行的关系。苏亚雷斯制作了一封电子邮件，其中弗拉布利奇询问伊万卡是否愿意出现在其宣传视频中。伊万卡表示，她不记得自己是否制作了这段视频，但补充说，德意志银行一直在说“他们非常欣赏我们的关系。”苏亚雷斯还提到了 2013 年 3 月唐纳德·特朗普与德意志银行时任联合首席执行官安舒·贾恩 (Anshu Jain) 在特朗普大厦的一次会面。伊万卡似乎对这次会议有着清晰的记忆。她声称贾恩鼓励特朗普家族与该银行开展更多业务。当苏亚雷斯问她父亲对这次会议有何反应时，她说：“他非常积极。这是一次非常愉快的会议。” ♦

;两个半月前，明尼苏达州最高选举官员史蒂夫·西蒙 (Steve Simon) 收到来自人民言论自由组织 (FSFP) 的一封信，这是一个倡导民主原则的小型无党派组织。这封信要求西蒙作为国务卿做一些以前从未做过的事情：阻止前总统，;唐纳德·特朗普< /a>;，出现在该州 2024 年选举选票上。 “根据美国宪法第十四修正案，特朗普先生因参与针对美国的叛乱而没有资格参加未来的任何联邦职位投票，”声明称。 “允许一名已知的叛乱分子出现在选票上，不符合你之前的承诺和支持美国宪法的就职誓言。”

;

;民主党人西蒙不太确定。第十四修正案第 3 条规定，任何宣誓维护宪法，然后参与叛乱的人，或者向参与叛乱的人提供帮助或安慰的人，都被取消担任任何公职或军事职务的资格。但西蒙告诉我，他对个别候选人的资格不持立场。他希望法官来决定选票是否可以包含特朗普的名字。 “我们的工作是为选民服务，让法院进行事实调查并做出法律结论，”他告诉我。 “人们期望担任这个职位的人会把他们的政治抛在一边。 。 。不要做出任何让任何候选人、任何政党或任何选票问题看起来像是用拇指衡量的事情。”

;

;西蒙收到这封信的那天，保罗·安德森 (Paul Anderson) 是一位退休的退休人员明尼苏达州最高法院的法官恰好在州议会大厦，准备带一些客人参观这座大楼。安德森在球场上待了十九年，直到达到七十岁的法定退休年龄。 （他现在已经八十岁了。）一生中大部分时间都是温和派共和党人，2016 年提名特朗普为总统候选人后，他与该党决裂。当查尔斯·瑙恩 (Charles Nauen) 出现在圆形大厅时，他是一位著名律师，其客户包括明尼苏达州分公司。民主党的代表过来聊天。

;

;Nauen 告诉安德森，他和 FSFP 对国务卿西蒙提起诉讼，这可能迫使西蒙阻止特朗普参加该州的初选。此案将由安德森在明尼苏达州最高法院的前同事审理。然后，瑙恩提出了一个非正统的要求：安德森会考虑成为该案的请愿人吗？

;

;“我回避了查理的直接问题，”安德森告诉我。 “查理似乎接受了我不同意参与诉讼的事实。”然而，在接下来的几天里，他们的谈话进一步深入。安德森仔细权衡了瑙恩的要求。如果他加入诉讼，一位长期任职的共和党人将挑战民主党人，以期限制唐纳德·特朗普。 “我们在这里处理的事情远远超出了党派标签的范围，”他告诉我。最终，当 FSFP 和 Nauen 于 9 月 12 日对西蒙提起诉讼时，安德森是请愿书中八名备受瞩目的明尼苏达州人之一。

;

;明尼苏达州是非营利组织招募高级人才的三个州之一。 - 包括现任和前任共和党人在内的选民将提起第 3 条诉讼。 FSFP 与当地律师一起在密歇根州提起了一个类似的案件，旨在迫使国务卿乔斯林·本森将特朗普的名字从选票上删除。与此同时，在科罗拉多州，无党派监督组织华盛顿公民责任与道德组织 (;CREW;) 正在起诉特朗普和科罗拉多州国务卿耶娜·格里斯沃尔德 (Jena Griswold)。具有讽刺意味的是，该诉讼将他们两人列为共同被告：格里斯沃尔德认为特朗普对国家构成威胁，并指责他;1 月 6 日袭击美国国会大厦;，并认为这一天是叛乱。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在未来的一年里，这些案件可能会加剧政治分歧并蒙上阴影2024 年大选的不确定性。 1 月 6 日袭击背后的特朗普支持者声称选举被窃取；既然他们的暴力行为以及特朗普在其中所扮演的角色已经引发了诉讼，更多关于选举被盗或被操纵的指控可能会随之而来。就连作为明尼苏达州请愿者的安德森也担心，如果特朗普真的被取消选举资格会发生什么。 “我非常担心这可能会导致人们变得暴力，”他告诉我。 “有些人想要投票给他，并认为投票给他是他们的权利，这是一个可怕的提议。”

;

;11 月 2 日，FSFP 向明尼苏达州最高法院提起诉讼。在听证会上，法官们似乎最感兴趣的是弄清楚州法院是否在有关第 3 条的宪法问题中发挥作用。 FSFP 律师罗恩·费恩 (Ron Fein) 发言几分钟后，首席法官娜塔莉·哈德森 (Natalie Hudson) 问他一个问题：问题：即使法院有权将特朗普的名字从选票中删除，是否应该这样做？哈德森说：“这是我最关心的问题。”

;

;对此，费恩表示，特朗普随时可以“向美国最高法院寻求审查，这可以为问题提供最终答案”。他对判例法的了解似乎是百科全书式的。他指出明尼苏达州的一项法规，他说，该法规让法官别无选择，只能在这里做出裁决。

;
;
;

;周三晚上，他们做到了。法院表示，明尼苏达州法律并不禁止主要政党将不合格的候选人列入初选。它认为，无论第 3 条是否取消特朗普的总统职位资格，特朗普都可以参加投票。即便如此，案件可能还没有结束。正如费恩指出的那样，上诉最终可能会提交至最高法院。与此同时，法院允许请愿者选择在大选期间提出相同的要求。 “法院的意见并不令人意外，”安德森在周四的一封电子邮件中告诉我。 “法院暂时推迟了主要问题，并将主要问题推迟了一天。”

;
;
;

;;CREW;在科罗拉多州针对格里斯沃尔德和特朗普的案件开始于10 月 30 日。 ;CREW;简报以令人难以忍受的细节列出了特朗普在 1 月 6 日袭击事件中的共谋，并认为，如果格里斯沃尔德允许特朗普参加初选，那将是“一种不当行为”。他们的目击者包括两名在国会大厦击退骚乱者的警察和一名描述躲避袭击者的民主党国会议员。对此，特朗普的律师辩称，前总统没有煽动1月6日的袭击，这不是叛乱。他们试图让法官将前总统的案件与格里斯沃尔德的案件分开，但未能成功。

;

;格里斯沃尔德和她的选举官员同事的处境很复杂。 “我们希望法院能够澄清第十四修正案第 3 条是否适用于选票，”她告诉我。 As the Minnesota ruling suggests, Trump may be found eligible to appear on the ballot regardless of his eligibility to be sworn in as President. But Griswold added, “We've never had a President incite an insurrection and attack our democracy like Trump has.” A ruling in the Colorado case is expected by Thanksgiving.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;

;
;

;

;No matter the outcome, the stakes will be high. After ;CREW; filed its case, the chair of the Colorado Republican Party called the lawsuit ;treasonous; and said, “We won't take it lying down.” Griswold's office received more than sixty death threats and nine hundred abusive calls. The reaction was so intense that the judge overseeing the case, in Colorado's Second Judicial District Court, issued a protective order to keep the parties safe. (The Colorado petitioners are not talking to the press.) Meanwhile, in Michigan, the office of Secretary of State Benson, who encountered armed protesters after the 2020 election, was inundated with “very vitriolic messages on both sides,” she told me. “I very clearly said, In Michigan, the former President is going to be on the ballot unless the court rules otherwise. That's turned the volume down a bit on some of the threats.”

;

;Congress passed three ;Reconstruction amendments; in the years after the Civil War. The Thirteenth Amendment abolished slavery, while the Fifteenth Amendment established voting rights for all men (women had to wait another fifty years). The Fourteenth Amendment is best known for granting citizenship to “all persons born or naturalized in the United States” and for securing due process and equal protection of the laws “to any person within its jurisdiction.” But lawmakers of the time were also grappling with a thorny dilemma: what to do about former secessionists who wanted to hold political office in the newly mended nation.

;

;After the ratification of the Fourteenth Amendment, in 1868, Section 3 was used to remove former Confederates from Congress, and to keep others out of office. But, in 1872, Congress granted amnesty to those who aided and abetted the Confederacy. As a result, Section 3 was mostly forgotten—until the storming of the Capitol on January 6, 2021. Armed Trump supporters, encouraged by the outgoing President, breached the halls of Congress in order to disrupt the certification of the election. Trump watched from the White House and, for hours, did nothing to stop them. In the days afterward, many observers, including high-ranking Republicans, were calling it an insurrection. Section 3 suddenly seemed timely and prescient.

;

;The petitioners in Minnesota, Michigan, and Colorado are not the first to note that Section 3 might disqualify Trump from becoming President again. “In fact, the articles of impeachment against Trump, in 2021, mentioned Section 3,” Fein, who is also litigating the Michigan case, said. “But we were the first to realize that Section 3 can be enforced using existing state law.” What he means is that each state has its own rules about which candidates can appear on ballots; if Trump really is ineligible for the Presidency, under Section 3, some states could stop him from being listed at all.

;

;In 2022, in one of several precedents for the current lawsuits, Fein and his colleagues ;challenged; ;Marjorie Taylor Greene;'s eligibility to run for reëlection under Section 3, in a filing addressed to Georgia's secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger. Greene, a Trump acolyte, had encouraged supporters to protest the certification of Biden's victory, calling it their “1776 moment.” ;Fein lost; the case. “The evidence does not show Rep. Greene engaged in months of planning and plotting to bring about the Invasion and defeat the orderly transfer of power provided for in our Constitution,” the judge wrote.

;

;Fein's team also sought to prevent Representative ;Madison Cawthorn;, of North Carolina, from running for reëlection, arguing that he had helped to incite the insurrection through his public remarks. After the North Carolina State Board of Elections determined that it had the authority to decide whether Cawthorn was disqualified under Section 3, the chief judge of the US District Court for the Eastern District of North Carolina ;ruled; that the amnesty of 1872 essentially repealed Section 3. While the appeal was pending, Cawthorn lost his primary, and the question of whether he was qualified for office lost relevance. But ;CREW; lawyers had better luck in New Mexico. In September, 2022, they successfully used Section 3 ;to remove; a sitting county commissioner who had participated in the attack on the Capitol.

;
;
;

;Any court that takes up the question of Trump's eligibility under Section 3 will have to start by deciding whether the section remains in force today, or whether it is a historical artifact that was meant to apply solely to Civil War rebels. If it is still in effect, the court will then be tasked with untying various semantic knots. Does Section 3 apply to the Presidency? What constitutes an insurrection? What exactly are “aid” and “comfort”? Notably, Section 3 does not mention elections, and it was written before primaries existed; the Minnesota Supreme Court pointed out that, in the state, a primary is an internal party matter, outside the jurisdiction of the secretary of state. In a sense, what's ultimately on trial is the meaning of Section 3 itself.

;

;Fein and his colleagues at FSFP launched their effort to disqualify Trump in June, 2021, by sending preliminary letters to every chief election officer in the country. The letters argued that, if Trump tried to seek the Presidency again, he would be ineligible under Section 3—and that secretaries of state had the authority and the obligation to keep him off the ballot. As soon as Trump declared his intention to run again, in November, 2022, FSFP announced that it would be challenging him in multiple states.

;

;An effort to disqualify a popular politician, using a constitutional clause that had essentially laid dormant for a century and a half, may seem quixotic or even misguided. This summer, however, a pre-publication draft of a ;law-review article; made the case that Section 3 disqualifies Trump from the Presidency. Law reviews rarely make news, but this one did—not only because of its careful reasoning but because its two authors, William Baude and Michael Stokes Paulsen, are well-known conservative jurists. Both are members of the Federalist Society, which interprets the Constitution through an originalist lens; their jurisprudence derives from what they see as the intent of the Framers, based on both a semantic and historical analysis of the text.

;

;There are two main conclusions that Baude and Paulsen reach. First, January 6th was an insurrection—shorter in duration than the Civil War, obviously, but with no less of an intent to subvert the constitutional order. Second, because Donald Trump took an oath to preserve and protect the Constitution when he was sworn into office in 2017, and because Section 3 explicitly disqualifies any insurrectionist who has taken such an oath, it applies to Trump. They write that, whatever one calls January 6th, “such conduct is covered by Section Three, and is disqualifying.” The fact that a law has not been dusted off in decades, they note, does not render it moot: “The First Amendment is old too, as is the entire original Constitution. But both remain in force.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Fein told me that the article, which is slated to run in the ;University of Pennsylvania Law Review; next year, “injected a great deal of new energy into the national conversation about these issues, and helped to elevate them—and, perhaps, give some gravitas that this is not a partisan issue.” There was considerable overlap between Baude and Paulsen's arguments, Fein said, and the ones that his team was already preparing to make in court. “It agrees with what we have been researching and saying for years now,” he said.

;

;Perhaps the most powerful objection to using Section 3 to keep Trump off the ballot is that it is undemocratic to prevent the American people from voting for the candidate of their choice. This is the position of another prominent conservative jurist, Michael W. McConnell. “We are talking about empowering partisan politicians such as state secretaries of state to disqualify their political opponents from the ballot, depriving voters of the ability to elect candidates of their choice,” McConnell ;has said;. “If abused, this is profoundly anti-democratic.” McConnell cites a landmark 1964 civil-rights decision, in Reynolds v. Sims, which declared: “The right to vote freely for the candidate of one's choice is of the essence of a democratic society, and any restrictions on that right strike at the heart of representative government.”

;

;Baude and Paulsen counter that this is a political argument, not a legal one—and the Constitution, in their view, is apolitical. There are already restrictions on the people Americans can vote for: a Presidential candidate must be a natural-born American over the age of thirty-five, and the Twenty-second Amendment prohibits a two-term President from running again, even if voters are willing to elect them. There is also precedent for enforcing these restrictions on the state level. Before ;Neil Gorsuch; became a Supreme Court Justice, he sat on the US Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit. In 2012, he ruled that Scott Gessler, the Republican secretary of state of Colorado at the time, had the right to “exclude from the ballot candidates who are constitutionally prohibited from assuming office.” (In a curious twist, Gessler is now one of Trump's lawyers in the Colorado litigation.)

;

;There are many possible outcomes here. Whether judges rule in favor of Trump or against him, they may trigger an appeal. In Colorado and Michigan, lower-court judges could also decide that the cases are not “ripe”—that is, not ready for adjudication because the issue that they raise is not imminent. Trump hasn't run or won yet, so the question of his disqualification is arguably in the future. (Minnesota's laws are a bit different; all eligibility challenges to federal candidates go straight to the state's highest court.)

;

;A Supreme Court decision could potentially adjudicate these cases in various ways. It could agree with Trump's lawyers that January 6th was not an insurrection or, if it was, that Trump was not materially involved. Or it could accept the argument of a lawyer for Trump in Minnesota, Nicholas Nelson—that courts shouldn't decide “who can or can't be President.” It could also subscribe to Baude and Paulsen's originalist reading of Section 3, and disqualify the former President.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;If the Supreme Court does take on this challenge, they are most likely to take Michael W. McConnell's advice and rule as narrowly as possible, to prevent Section 3 from being abused in the future. ;Richard Hasen;, an elections-law expert who directs the Safeguarding Democracy Project at UCLA, told me that he is less concerned with how the Court rules than that they do so very quickly. “Sometimes it's more important for the law to be certain than to be right,” he said. “It will be a disaster if Trump wins the election, and Democrats control Congress, and they don't let him assume the Presidency because they say he's not qualified. And, for Republican voters, they shouldn't be voting for a candidate who's not qualified. So this needs resolution.”

;
;
;

;For Anderson, the retired Minnesota Supreme Court justice, the real question is: “should Trump, under our system of rule, be held accountable for his actions?” That's what convinced him, finally, to add his name to the lawsuit. “The American system of democracy is just so deeply rooted in me that, when somebody makes an assault on it, I'm offended,” he told me. “Benjamin Franklin said, 'It's a republic if you can keep it.' And so I'm willing to stand up and try to keep it.” ♦

;The night that I saw Geoff Sobelle's “FOOD,” something went wrong—and thank heavens it did.索贝尔是一位出色的小丑，这也说明了当事情不顺利时他也能游刃有余。 （小丑，至少像劳雷尔和哈代或巴斯特·基顿这样的喜剧演员，往往会选择愚蠢的、弄巧成拙的道路，因此任何障碍都会让任务变得更加滑稽。）索贝尔的单人制作，在布鲁克林音乐学院的菲什曼空间，围绕一张巨大的方桌进行，每边大约二十英尺，摆着餐盘、银器和白色桌布。三十名观众被允许拉起一把椅子，而我们其余的人则坐在三边高高的剧院座位上。索贝尔是我们的领班，他和蔼可亲、始终彬彬有礼的表情流露出耐心，而他的客人却挫败了他让夜晚顺利进行的企图。压力增大；他的耐受力明显增强。 It's delicious.

;

;Sobelle comes from the French clowning tradition of Jacques Lecoq, which sees the clown as a sacred innocent—there are no big circus shoes here, no ritual humiliation, no squirting flower.索贝尔是一个眼神善良、身材矮小的人，看起来有点像没有喝开胃酒的斯坦利·图奇(Stanley Tucci)，他开发了一种做法，将这个天真无邪的角色融入到一个精心构建的梦想世界中，这个世界通常只专注于一个想法或图像。在《实物课程》（2014）中，他用成百上千个纸板箱填满了整个鱼人空间，里面装满了一辆停在微型红绿灯处的微型汽车，以及一个真人大小的客厅的组件。 ——它让我们既爱又恨我们自己的一堆东西。在《家》（2017）中，他建造了一座变幻莫测的二层房子，探索家庭生活的沧桑。 For “FOOD,” he has given up some of his customary splendor, perhaps because his theme this time is unbridled consumption.

;

;Sobelle and his co-director, Lee Sunday Evans, as well as Sobelle's co-creator, the magician Steve Cuiffo, have designed a loosely connected buffet of events, a kind of cabaret of appetite.例如，索贝尔穿着黑白服务员的衣服，表演了一段延长的腹部戏法，他似乎吃掉了晚餐的所有剩菜，将芹菜茎和一包点燃的香烟塞进了他的食道。 Each dish requires a different trick in order to make it disappear, but the effect remains: whether he gobbles a raw onion or drains two bottles of red, we reflect on gluttony.

;

;As Sobelle dashes around the table, graciously proffering wine, he quietly urges the audience to pitch in. He presses one theatregoer into taking on sommelier duties (“A dirty little Brooklyn Beaujolais?” she suggests to the group) and guides several others into ordering from a menu. He'll do anything to fulfill our wishes: in one quick gag, he snowshoes across the trackless ice of the Arctic—which happens to look just like our white tabletop—to catch an Arctic char.

;

;Almost no one gets to eat in “FOOD,” apart from Sobelle himself, though the folks at the table are offered a generous pour.他希望我们感到好奇，而不是满足。影片开场思考饥饿如何驱使单细胞生物发育出嘴巴，然后是腿，最后是武器。而且，在节目的最后一个动作中，一位观众引导了索贝尔作为口技表演者的独白。餐桌上的那个人，索贝尔的双手轻轻地放在后脑勺上，不知何故凭直觉列出了一份长长的、复杂的食物清单，从我们生命形式最初吃的东西（泥土、水）一直到人类最新的食物美味佳肴（不可能的肉，Tofurky）。 This is where our voraciousness has led us, “FOOD” says—from the unknowable depths of the sea to the Cronut.

;
;
;

;For the first time at one of Sobelle's shows, I found myself thinking, I get it.这里有一个特定的鼓点：人是从食欲进化而来的；人是从食欲进化而来的。现在他吃掉了世界。但索贝尔自身神奇的灵活性（你不能让小丑感到惊讶，因为他们总是准备好让别人扔馅饼）意味着他可以即时创造新的含义。在节目中的某个时刻，他露出了藏在桌布下的一大片泥土，他带领一群玩具大小的野牛穿过它，将其变成了大平原的立体模型。我去的那天晚上，一位去剧院的人在桌子上留下了一个蓝色的塑料吸管杯，当索贝尔把布迅速拿走时，它并没有随着餐具的其他设置一起消失。突然，他和他的小野牛不得不面对一个（相对）巨大的绿松石色玻璃杯，它落在西部中部。索贝尔并没有忽视这一点；相反，他将他的小群聚集在杯子周围安静地沉思。野牛崇拜这个外星物体吗？他们是否在展望我们充满塑料的未来？ It felt a little like the beginning of “2001: A Space Odyssey,” when the obelisk appears among the apes.

;

;The same week I went to ;BAM;, I saw two other gifted clowns of quite different types, one poignant, one absurdist, and it struck me, as it always does, how good the form is at conveying resolve in the face of adversity. Clowns try their hardest to succeed, but the world has other ideas—if a clown does manage to step over a banana peel, he'll inevitably fall into an open manhole.

;

;In “Redwood,” Brittany K. Allen's crisp comedy at Off Off Broadway's Ensemble Studio Theatre, Tyrone Mitchell Henderson, a willowy comic virtuoso, plays Stevie, a man constantly sending pestering e-mails about Ancestry.com to his unresponsive family.他发现他的侄女梅格（艾伦饰演）和她的白人男友德鲁（德鲁刘易斯饰演）之间存在基因联系，德鲁的祖先似乎奴役了他们的祖先（并生了孩子）。尴尬的对话随之而来。由米哈埃拉·马霍尼 (Mikhaela Mahony) 执导的精心调配的整体笑声不断，但该剧的核心人物是史蒂夫 (Stevie)，他幽默而懂事，有一种无限开放的感觉，让观众通过他的眼睛看到世界。在艾伦最敏锐的触动中，她在最后一幕中将家族的第一个被奴役的祖先阿拉米达（布林·卡特饰）带到了舞台上，作为一个灵魂对她的后代进行了抱怨。阿拉米达讨厌她的黑人家庭成员拥抱他们的（远房）白人表弟。但史蒂夫像皮埃罗一样娇弱忧郁，自信双倍，没有听到她的咒骂。 He raises a glass to the past, and he carries on.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Finally, I saw one of our original clowns.实验砖剧院上演的《浮士德》是对歌德 19 世纪杰作的前几部分的美丽、冗长、令人心碎的改编，讲述了一位德国魔导师与魔鬼的白痴讨价还价。眼神狂野、留着探矿者胡须的埃里克·戴尔 (Eric Dyer) 几十年来一直在他的前卫公司 Radiohole 中制作节目，但这一次他几乎完全独自工作，担任编剧、表演者、舞台监督、董事会操作员、胡子和胸部- 梳发师、布景设计师和技术人员。 If you're going to sell your soul, no one else is going to help out.

;

;Dyer's aesthetic involves cartoon-style drawings, outlined with heavy black markers, sometimes worn as masks, sometimes deployed in a terrifying puppet show.这些图像，例如小孤儿安妮的眼神空洞的天使，通过对话气球进行交谈，戴尔以肥皂盒式的咆哮风格滔滔不绝地讲出一段奇怪的文字，涉及 F. W. Murnau 1926 年的电影版《浮士德》，以及在艺术中​​赚钱是不可能的。该布景是一个金属框架盒子，就像一个烧毁的游乐场摊位，戴尔将其用作部分 DJ 站和部分微型剧院 - 他使用磁铁将他的图画从框架的支柱上固定或分离，然后将插图扔到地上。当不再需要它们时，会采取一些暴力。戴尔专注于一种神圣的失败：他通过手机运行技术提示，然后将手机递给观众，鼓励他们猛烈地敲击控制器，并试图通过画一个五角星来调用超自然力量，这是一种努力在仪式中途崩溃了。他在这里是在比喻成功吗？魔鬼不接他的电话吗？是的，是的。对于这位中世纪与市中心相遇的超级小丑来说，剧院首先是香蕉皮，然后是沙井。他告诉我们，在那之后，看起来就像是直接通往地狱。 ♦

;In the years since the pandemic began, the experience of dining out has been utterly transformed.令人垂涎的桌子现在在发布后几秒钟就消失了，而有影响力的人则决定了需求，甚至是菜单上的内容。在本期《Critics at Large》中，特约撰稿人 Vinson Cunningham、Naomi Fry 和 Alexandra Schwartz 阐述了我们新的烹饪景观。 The hosts are joined by Hannah Goldfield, who covers restaurants and food culture for ;The New Yorker;.他们一起思考 TikTok 如何改变我们的饮食方式，以及 Resy 的崛起如何给预订游戏带来稀缺感和竞争感。然后，评论家们讨论了弗雷德里克·怀斯曼 (Frederick Wiseman) 的一部新纪录片《Menus-Plaisirs - Les Troisgros》，讲述了一家米其林星级法国餐厅的故事，该片以一种截然不同的幕后视角展示了精致餐饮中的劳动和创造力。这些例子提出了如何平衡艺术与艺术及其周围的体验的问题。一个答案是在那些避开炒作的场所中找到的，这提醒我们首先为什么要外出就餐。 “我不需要感受这场斗争和胜利的宏大戏剧，”施瓦茨说。 “I simply want to feel welcomed.”

;;IV. MISERY;

;

;My men were dehydrated and hungry.我将剩余面粉的配给量增加了一倍，这导致他们更多地呕吐和死亡。 There was nothing that would please them.

;

;Then I heard a voice crying out from the distance. “上帝啊，伙计，把你的船停在这里吧！”我舔了舔干裂、血淋淋的嘴唇，眯着眼睛看着水面。这是我想象的吗？ “我有食物和水，”那个声音继续说道。 “很多火腿三明治。 Just toss me a line.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The surviving men gathered on deck and gazed at the ominous figure on the opposite bank from which we'd launched. We knew much less about the inhabitants of that neighborhood.

;
;
;

;“Cannibal,” I muttered. “他是个食人者，他在欺骗我们。”然后，大声说道：“所说的火腿三明治里的肉是从哪里来的？回答这个问题，否则你就会看到我们的船尾！” My men cheered weakly.

;

;“I have ham sandwiches,” the savage said more quietly, feigning confusion.

;

;“McGann, set sail for Tahiti,” I said through gritted teeth.

;

;“Aye, aye, sir,” McGann said, then died and, considering the greater good, lined it up so that his body flopped overboard and didn't have to be wrapped in a flag, and prayed over and all that.

;

;Moments later, Tover McCloon lacked the same civility and allowed his dead body to fall on deck.我命令我们开始我们平常的小仪式。但我的船员没有让步。他们的饥饿和口渴开始超出他们举办小型葬礼的能力。讽刺的是，当我们慢慢远离对岸的食人者时，我们发现自己在争论吃麦克克隆的利弊。一方面，他是一位忠实的船友和朋友。 On the other, a little food in our bellies would surely bolster our energy levels.

;

;“Please don't do it!”他的遗孀在岸上喊道。我们考虑到了这一点，但知道她有偏见，因为她嫁给了他。 I'm unproud to say we hesitantly passed forks and knives around and closed our eyes, and did that awful deed and got extremely full from it, and therefore napped, appropriately ashamed, but also very sleepy.

;

;;V. VICTORY;

;

;As I would write years later in my book, “How to Sail and Conquer,” having an entire crew and its captain nap at the same time is tempting fate.坚韧号漂得太靠近食人海岸，船体被码头撕开。我醒来发现船体里积满了水。 I shook my napping crew, but they'd all died of scurvy and/or been bitten to death by rats, drowned, etc.

;
;
;

;The Fortitude was lowering herself into the Thames a few feet per hour, and there was nothing I could do.诸神似乎下定决心让我永远不要亲吻一个赤裸上身的塔希提人。 And, being realistic, I realized the gods would not even allow me to see the next sunset.

;

;I'd never learned to swim and so, with a sheepish glance toward my father, I lay down to nap again, hoping I could be asleep when I drowned, if that was a thing.

;
;
;

;I woke an hour later, feeling frustrated that I'd have to drown awake, but found that a bit of providence had finally shone upon me. The river's level had lowered, and I could make out a sort of bridge to shore, composed of crewmembers' bodies.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In what was later described as the most courageous first step that any man has ever taken, I set one foot firmly on Tover McCloon's dead face, pushed down a few times to test the sturdiness, then stepped fully from the sinking Fortitude.

;

;Crowds watched as I tottered along the body bridge, surely a sight to behold, with my hungry belly and stubbly face.最后，四个多小时以来，我第一次感觉到脚下的土地非常甜蜜。当围观者爆发出欢呼声时，我泪流满面，亲吻了泥土。但随后哭声就沉寂了。 I looked up to find my father gazing down with a scowl on his craggy face.

;

;“Young man,” he said, “because of what you have just done, you will never have to lift a finger again in your life.你体现了作为一个好英国男人的含义。 Now stand up and shake my hand, and then kneel down again because the king is here to congratulate you!”

;

;And it was true.人群分开，乔治三世国王现身。 He leaned close to me and whispered, “Don't know that I could have done it any better myself, lad.”

;

;The crowd erupted, and I realized that this was very deserved. I may not have accomplished every part of the mission exactly as we'd set out to do, but it was very possible that I'd done much more than that.

;
;

;The Republican Presidential primary has been a curiously hidden contest: with Donald Trump ;effectively boycotting; the trail, the remaining candidates have mostly struggled to draw the attention of potential supporters and the political press, both of whom seem sure that the real action is elsewhere.但到周三晚上第三场共和党辩论结束时，初选的主要进展已经变得清晰起来。 Nikki Haley is the best debater in the field, and she would probably be the GOP's most effective opponent to ;Joe Biden;. “你想要迪克·切尼穿三英寸高跟鞋吗？” ;Vivek Ramaswamy;, who has been baiting the former South Carolina governor all campaign, asked the audience at one point.海莉的回答引起了欢呼：“这是五英寸高的高跟鞋。” But she didn't disavow Cheney.

;

;The debate was held a day after the 2023 elections, and the results of Tuesday night—headlined by Republican losses in Ohio, Kentucky, and Virginia— seemed to liberate the Presidential candidates, at least to a degree.如果特朗普的政党不再取得胜利，那么也许他的对手就不需要向他表现出如此毫无疑问的忠诚。佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯在主持人的敦促下对特朗普提出了一些批评，他说：“我厌倦了共和党的失败。”拉马斯瓦米谴责了特朗普精心挑选的共和党全国委员会主席罗娜·麦克丹尼尔，正如拉马斯瓦米指出的那样，她主持了四次令人失望的政党选举。但黑莉比其他挑战者更认识到，选举性争论不太可能对特朗普造成太大损害。相反，她在政策上追随他。黑利说，特朗普“在乌克兰问题上曾经是正确的”。 “Now he's getting weak in the knees.”

;

;Give her points for consistency.在海莉眼里，其他人都是废物。她指责德桑蒂斯和特朗普迎合，称他们不会削减医疗保险和社会保障福利，然后承诺提高退休年龄。她独自斥责德桑蒂斯反对在佛罗里达大沼泽地钻探。 “罗恩继续这样做让我很高兴——他反对水力压裂，他反对钻探，”黑利在谈到佛罗里达州州长时说。 “他受到塞拉俱乐部的赞扬，而你正在努力弥补这一点，并在环境问题上表现得好像你不是一个自由主义者。”她对拉马斯瓦米抱有特别的蔑视。在他批评海莉成年女儿使用 TikTok 后，她对他说：“你就是人渣。”在拉马斯瓦米拒绝美国向乌克兰提供进一步支持的想法后，她说：“我告诉你们，普京和习主席对这样的人可能成为总统垂涎欲滴。”她说，伊朗“对实力做出反应——你打他们一次，用力打他们，他们就会退缩。”有人问她，在以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡与哈马斯的战争中，她会给他什么建议？她说她已经向他提出了：“完成它们。 Finish them.”

;
;
;

;This wasn't exactly a surgical performance.海莉是一根大棒。她是一位经验丰富的政治家，经常会以一些同情的声明开始——“作为一名退伍军人的妻子”； “作为一个母亲”——但她常常很快就会发起攻击。自2016年以来，共和党顾问一直在说，党的选民最想要的是一个愿意为他们而战的人，而海莉的军事姿态是如此持续和全方位，这在某种程度上掩盖了她正在为事情而战的事实（一个直截了当的新保守主义者）海外政策、削减福利的姿态），而特朗普时代的共和党人本应搁置这些。但在周三晚上的辩论中闭上眼睛（至少在拉马斯瓦米不说话的那段时间），那可能是 2007 年，也可能是 2011 年。其他候选人取代了黑利。 At one point, the South Carolina Senator ;Tim Scott;, the nice guy in the field, alarmingly called for strikes against Iran.

;

;Politically, Haley is a loner—that has always been one of her limitations.在南卡罗来纳州，她的迅速崛起引发了州共和党内部的激烈竞争。她并不真正属于基督教右翼或极端自由主义，但她也不是温和派。当我在路上看到她时，她往往会让观众感到冷淡——他们似乎想知道，这一切都是为了谁？本周在爱荷华州，共和党州长金·雷诺兹最终决定不再支持特朗普。 But, despite the fact that ;Haley; is the candidate with momentum recently, Reynolds backed DeSantis (and in the process may have helped revive his flagging campaign in the state).但从另一种意义上说，海莉的独立是一份礼物，因为它使她能够自由地进行攻击。在早期的州民意调查中，她的支持率刚刚超过百分之十——几乎没有什么会让特朗普感到不安的。但周三关于外交政策的辩论焦点对她有利，如果这是一个转折点，黑莉开始直接反对特朗普，那么总统初选可能会变得更加有趣。 Unlike Chris Christie, whose potency as a debater was wildly overhyped, Nikki Haley can land a punch.

;

;By the end of Wednesday night's debate, it seemed that Haley might have found a way to do so against Trump. 2016年之前，共和党人花了一代人的时间选择最严格的自由市场主义者和最不复杂的国防鹰派作为提名人。捍卫权利并批评美国海外影响力的民主党人缺乏决心。但是，如果特朗普与这些保守的正统观念保持距离，那么为什么他不能也被攻击为软弱呢？特朗普在民意调查中的优势，以及迄今为止共和党初选的低调，可能意味着他永远不必真正应对这一挑战。但如果他这样做的话，看看会发生什么将会很有趣。 The blue-ribbon ;;Times;/Siena poll; out this week has Trump beating Biden in five of the six swing states, and trailing the incumbent President only in Wisconsin, where Biden is up by two points.但同一项民意调查还询问威斯康星州选民他们更喜欢拜登还是黑利。十三岁时，他们去找了海莉。 ♦

;On the second episode of “The Golden Bachelor,” ABC's new “Bachelor” spinoff, the titular protagonist, a onetime Indiana restaurateur named Gerry, sits down for some one-on-one time with Leslie, a fitness instructor from Minneapolis who is one of the women competing to win his heart.分享完之后，尽管她外表自信，但她很敏感，内心柔软，“就像熔岩蛋糕”，莱斯利接着告诉格里，她还有一件事要说。 “如果你想在我耳边低语甜言蜜语，我就能听到你的声音，”她一边说，一边把长长的棕色头发往后梳，露出她的助听器。也戴着助听器的格里显然很感动。 “I thought that was really kind of darling,” he later tells the camera, his eyes moist.

;

;Since “The Bachelor” began airing, in 2002, a big part of the appeal of the series and its long-running corollary, “The Bachelorette,” has been its casts' youthful good looks.这在该系列最成功的衍生剧《天堂单身汉》中表现得尤为明显，该剧现已在电视上播出九季。 (“Bombshell: Bachelor Nation Stars Who Have the Most Insane Bikini Bodies—See Them All!,” as a tabloid ;headline; recently put it.) In its début season, however, “The Golden Bachelor” explores a new horizon for the franchise.就像过去的单身汉和单身女子一样，格里也在寻找爱情，但这并不是他第一次参加牛仔竞技表演。格里是一位头发花白的绅士，穿着整齐的纽扣衬衫，头发仍然浓密，他是一位热情洋溢的热心鳏夫，在结婚四十三年后，他的妻子因短暂的疾病去世了。如今他已经是一位七十二岁的爷爷了，女参赛者的年龄从六十岁到七十五岁不等。换句话说，比基尼身材的统计数据下降了，而助听器的统计数据却上升了。但《黄金学士》并不是一部毫无生气或令人沮丧的节目。虽然它的参与者不是春鸡，但他们的生活也远未结束。 These are people with hopes and dreams and desires, and, as I watched, I couldn't help but think that there was something pretty radical about a show that represents older people as still wanting more from life—romantically, emotionally, sexually—without pandering to younger viewers or infantilizing its mature subjects.

;

;To be sure, the premise of “The Golden Bachelor” is just as stilted as the original franchise's, whose formula it follows nearly to a T. In the six episodes that have aired so far, Gerry has attempted to get to know the ladies by going on a series of group activities and one-on-one dates—including a hot-air-balloon ride with Ellen, a seventy-one-year-old retired teacher and pickleball co-captain from Delray Beach, Florida, and a retro-diner meal with Theresa, a seventy-year-old financial-services professional from Shrewsbury, New Jersey.在上周四播出的最新一集中，格里通过一系列严重得像心脏病发作的“玫瑰仪式”，成功地将竞争者减少到三名决赛入围者。就像在《单身汉》中一样，这种筛选依赖于一种微妙的舞蹈，在这种舞蹈中，格里同时表达了对他潜在未婚夫的感情，让所有候选人都在发挥最大的观看张力，但并没有走得太远，把他描绘成粗心、不诚实的无赖与此同时，许多女士们毫不犹豫地表达了她们对他的近乎直接的爱和渴望，而且，就像《单身汉》中一样，这些求爱的迅速而突然的步伐让男人们暂时停止了怀疑。观众。 Could feeling really emerge sincerely under such rushed and artificial circumstances, especially given many of the contestants' previous experiences as happily married wives who have known long-standing, organic relationships?

;

;And yet, over the weeks, I could feel my native “Bachelor” skepticism ebbing.该系列长久以来的焦虑之一一直是参赛者是否“出于正确的原因”出现：他们参加节目是为了寻找爱情，还是只是为了获得名誉和财富？ After all, many “Bachelor” and “Bachelorette” alums have managed to leverage their newfound notoriety into lucrative careers as ;social-media influencers;.然而，这并不是格里和“黄金单身汉”女性所处的世界，这就是为什么观看这部剧感觉就像回到堕落前的伊甸园一样令人耳目一新。他们都过着自己的生活，而现在，在他们所剩的有限的时间里，他们似乎真正在寻找情感和陪伴，而不是名声。 At long last, the franchise is taking the initial premise of “The Bachelor” at its word.

;
;
;

;There's plenty of vulnerability here, and a lot of tears. “对于我们这个年纪的女性来说，遇到这样的人真的很难，”莱斯利说，当她承认自己爱上的格里与六十岁的高中老师费斯一起乘坐浪漫的直升机时。 “我希望我没有这样的感觉，”莱斯利后来抽泣着补充道。如果与格里不和，她还会有另一次恋爱机会吗？或者时间已经不多了？ （“我这个年纪的人多久有第二次爱情机会？”另一位参赛者，六十六岁的苏珊，反问道，呼应了这种情绪。）与此同时，特蕾莎还没有承认对她正在萌芽的感情。自她已故丈夫以来的任何人，那是五十二年前的事了。如果格里不回应她的感情怎么办？ “There's so much on the line,” she says, tremulously.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Surprisingly, even though emotions are running high, the show is remarkably devoid of the catfights among contestants that are a usual ;hallmark; of the franchise.一场短暂的不和——始于七十岁的退休教育顾问凯西，在特蕾莎夸耀她与格里的一对一约会时告诉她“快点结束”——是一个罕见的异常情况。在女士们生活的这个阶段，争吵似乎是浪费时间，而温暖的友谊几乎总是更可取的。当六十岁的私立学校管理员琼由于家庭危机需要离开时，尽管她刚刚在一次晚餐约会中与格里建立了牢固的联系，女人们和她一起哭泣，因为她告诉她们她希望“你们中的一个人爱上了格里。” “我的心都碎了，”苏珊说。 “我知道她有多想来这里。” As my colleague ;Alex Barasch; noted when we spoke of the series, it seems as if the contestants ;are; there to make friends.

;The show, too, doesn't shy away from depicting its protagonists as still libidinal.在我最喜欢的时刻之一，女士们足够大胆地在“我从来没有过”的游戏中公开讨论她们过去的恋爱经历。 （“我在工作场所发生过性行为，如果我结婚了，我还会再做一次！”七十五岁的桑德拉坚定地对着镜头说道。）而性火花并不是格里求爱过程中不可忽视的一部分。 。 （“我整夜醒来都在想你，”他告诉莱斯利，他称莱斯利为“一个非常性感的女人。”）这些女人显然也对格里有好感，每次他走进房间时，她们几乎都在欢呼。在“单身汉”时尚中，有大量的亲热行为——在热水浴缸里、在摩天轮上、在马背上——我不得不承认，这些行为的热情给了我对未来的希望。 Not dead yet!

;

;But, of course, it's not all fun and games, and the emotional stakes remain high, as we were reminded on Thursday's episode, in which Gerry visited the home towns of his final three choices—Theresa, Faith, and Leslie.与最初的“单身汉”相比，这里的大部分拷问和担忧的人不是参赛者的父母，而是他们的孩子。格里会善待他们的妈妈吗？他是那个人吗？ “我真的希望这件事能够成功。我真的希望他永远在我们的生活中，”特蕾莎的女儿说道，她的眼睛里充满了泪水。 “我不想让我妈妈受伤，”莱斯利的女儿说。 （“在你走到这一步之后，看到你的心碎了，我会感到很伤心，”她后来告诉她的母亲。）在玫瑰仪式上，格里必须选择最后两位女士，他选择了莱斯利，然后犹豫不决，无法选择第二个女人，这一集以悬念结束。 “我感觉我要吐了，”他说。 “不得不送人回家真是令人痛苦。”在观看了这部温柔温馨的节目六周后，我真的相信了他。 ♦
